articles.headline: Advertising’s Moral Struggle: Is Online Reach Worth the Hurt?
articles.snippet: Data and automation allow companies to connect with people anywhere on the internet, but that advertising also bankrolls sites toxic to society.
articles.abstract: Data and automation allow companies to connect with people anywhere on the internet, but that advertising also bankrolls sites toxic to society.
articles.lead_paragraph: Advertising on the internet has never been easier. Data and automation increasingly allow companies large and small to reach millions of people every month, and to tailor ads to specific groups based on their browsing habits or demographics.

articles.headline: Why Some of Your Holiday Gifts Might Not Fly
articles.snippet: Airlines are wary of drones and other devices with powerful batteries. And they won’t be as delighted as you are with that virtual reality headset.
articles.abstract: Airlines are wary of drones and other devices with powerful batteries. And they won’t be as delighted as you are with that virtual reality headset.
articles.lead_paragraph: The presents have been unwrapped. The batteries have been charged. Chances are, a few of those new gizmos may be designed to make air travel less stressful and more productive.

articles.headline: Seller-Financed Deals Are Putting Poor People in Lead-Tainted Homes
articles.snippet: The contracts relieve the true owner of the home of the responsibility for fixing it, and the result is more children with dangerous lead poisoning.
articles.abstract: The contracts relieve the true owner of the home of the responsibility for fixing it, and the result is more children with dangerous lead poisoning.
articles.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — A year after Tiffany Bennett moved into a two-story red brick house at 524 Loudon Avenue here, she received alarming news.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Will Donald Trump’s Corporate ‘Tax Holiday’ Create Jobs? Not Necessarily
articles.snippet: Corporate boards and executives are likely to use much of the cash to acquire businesses in the United States, to buy back their own stock or to pay down debt.
articles.abstract: Corporate boards and executives are likely to use much of the cash to acquire businesses in the United States, to buy back their own stock or to pay down debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has said he would like to create a “tax holiday” so that American companies can bring back profit that was generated overseas at a lower rate. In his view, this influx of cash will create jobs.

articles.headline: Trump’s Health Secretary Pick Leaves Nation’s Doctors Divided
articles.snippet: The American Medical Association endorsed the choice of Tom Price, a physician, but thousands of doctors have opposed it, citing Mr. Price’s opinions on health care and other issues.
articles.abstract: The American Medical Association endorsed the choice of Tom Price, a physician, but thousands of doctors have opposed it, citing Mr. Price’s opinions on health care and other issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President-elect Donald J. Trump chose Representative Tom Price of Georgia to be his health and human services secretary, the American Medical Association swiftly endorsed the selection of one of its own, an orthopedic surgeon who has championed the role of physicians throughout his legislative career.

articles.headline: China’s ‘Godfather of Real Estate’ Pitches Reverse Mortgages to Skeptical Elders
articles.snippet: As a rapidly graying population sparks worries about a pension bust, an important figure in the property business pushes a controversial solution.
articles.abstract: As a rapidly graying population sparks worries about a pension bust, an important figure in the property business pushes a controversial solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — He is known in China as the “godfather of real estate,” helping lay the groundwork for private homeownership in China, a move that enriched millions and laid the foundations for a vibrant and thriving Chinese middle class.

articles.headline: California, at Forefront of Climate Fight, Won’t Back Down to Trump
articles.snippet: An elevated role on climate change is a sign of how California, one of the world’s 10 largest economies, plans to resist the incoming administration’s policies.
articles.abstract: An elevated role on climate change is a sign of how California, one of the world’s 10 largest economies, plans to resist the incoming administration’s policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Foreign governments concerned about climate change may soon be spending more time dealing with Sacramento than Washington.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Henry Fountain

articles.headline: A Defiant Israel Vows to Expand Its Settlements
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended his response to the Security Council’s condemnation, saying that Israel does not “turn the other cheek.”
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu defended his response to the Security Council’s condemnation, saying that Israel does not “turn the other cheek.”
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Undeterred by a resounding defeat at the United Nations, Israel’s government said Monday that it would move ahead with thousands of new homes in East Jerusalem and warned nations against further action, declaring that Israel does not “turn the other cheek.”

articles.headline: Saudi Royal Family Is Still Spending in an Age of Austerity
articles.snippet: Low oil prices are forcing questions about whether the huge family can maintain both its lavish lifestyle and its grip on power.
articles.abstract: Low oil prices are forcing questions about whether the huge family can maintain both its lavish lifestyle and its grip on power.
articles.lead_paragraph: TANGIER, Morocco — Behind a tall perimeter wall, studded with surveillance cameras and guarded by Moroccan soldiers, a sprawling new palace for King Salman of Saudi Arabia rose on the Atlantic coast here last summer.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: China’s Cybersecurity Efforts Could Pose New Challenge for Foreign Firms
articles.snippet: A report by the Chinese internet regulator suggested it would formalize a cybersecurity review system on technology products in the country.
articles.abstract: A report by the Chinese internet regulator suggested it would formalize a cybersecurity review system on technology products in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It has been a tough year in China for America’s technology companies.
